translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
The eleventh section🔽The discussion on “This is suffering”

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When one says “This is suffering,” does the knowledge “This is suffering” occur?
“Yes.”

original: “Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: ayam dukkha samudayo ti vācam bhāsataḥ ayam dukkha samudayo ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When one says “This is the origin of suffering,” does the knowledge “This is the origin of suffering” occur?
“Is it so that one who is not a trainee is not a person who has entered upon the way?” …

original: “idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When one says “This is suffering,” does the knowledge “This is suffering” occur?
“Yes.”

original: “Ayaṁ dukkhanirodho”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “ayaṁ dukkhanirodho”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodho ti vācam bhāsataḥ ayam dukkha nirodho ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When one says “This is the cessation of suffering,” does the knowledge “This is the cessation of suffering” occur?
“Is it so that one who is not a trainee is not a person who has entered upon the way?” …

original: “idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When one says “This is suffering,” does the knowledge “This is suffering” occur?
“Yes.”

original: “Ayaṁ maggo”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “ayaṁ maggo”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: ayam maggo ti vācam bhāsataḥ ayam maggo ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When one says “This is the path,” does the knowledge “This is the path” occur?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: “Ayaṁ samudayo”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “ayaṁ samudayo”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: ayam samudayaḥ iti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca ayam samudayaḥ iti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When one says “This is the origin,” does the knowledge “This is the origin” occur?
“Yes.”

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘No.’ …
When he says, ‘This is the cessation of suffering,’ …

original: “ayaṁ maggo”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “ayaṁ maggo”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: ayam maggo ti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca ayam maggo ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering’?
You say ‘No.’ …

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge not occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘No.’ …

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘Yes.’ …

original: “Rūpaṁ aniccan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “rūpaṁ aniccan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: rūpam aniccanti vācam bhāsataḥ rūpam aniccanti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘Form is impermanent,’ does knowledge occur that ‘Form is impermanent’?
You say ‘No.’ …🔽When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?

original: “idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?🔽Āmantā.🔽Vedanā …
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti  āmantā  vedanā
translated: You say ‘Yes.’ …
When he says, ‘Feeling is impermanent,’ …🔽When he says, ‘Perception is impermanent,’ …
When he says, ‘Formations are impermanent,’ …

original: “viññāṇaṁ aniccan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “viññāṇaṁ aniccan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: viññāṇam aniccanti vācam bhāsataḥ viññāṇam aniccanti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘Consciousness is impermanent,’ does knowledge occur that ‘Consciousness is impermanent’?
You say ‘No.’ …

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
“Yes.”

original: “Rūpaṁ anattā”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “rūpaṁ anattā”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: rūpam anattā iti vācam bhāsataḥ rūpam anattā iti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘Form is not self,’ does knowledge occur that ‘Form is not self’?
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the past, the future, and the present?” …

original: “idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
“Yes.”
When he says, ‘Feeling is …
Perception is …
volitional formations are …

original: “viññāṇaṁ anattā”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “viññāṇaṁ anattā”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: viññāṇam anattā iti vācam bhāsataḥ viññāṇam anattā iti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: consciousness is not self,’ does knowledge occur that ‘Consciousness is not self’?
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye sense-sphere and in the mind-object sense-sphere?” …

original: “Rūpaṁ aniccan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “rūpaṁ aniccan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: rūpam aniccanti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca rūpam aniccanti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘Form is impermanent,’ does knowledge not occur that ‘Form is impermanent’?
“Yes.”

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge not occur that ‘This is suffering’?🔽“No.”
When he says, ‘Feeling is …
perception is …
volitional formations are …

original: “viññāṇaṁ aniccan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “viññāṇaṁ aniccan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: viññāṇam aniccanti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca viññāṇam aniccanti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: consciousness is impermanent,’ does knowledge not occur that ‘Consciousness is impermanent’?
“Yes.”

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘No.’ …

original: “Rūpaṁ anattā”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “rūpaṁ anattā”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: rūpam anattā ati vācam bhāsataḥ na ca rūpam anattā ati ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘Form is not self,’ does knowledge occur that ‘Form is not self’?
You say ‘Yes.’ …

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?

analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  vedanā
translated: You say ‘No.’ …
When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘Yes.’ …🔽When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?

original: “viññāṇaṁ anattā”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “viññāṇaṁ anattā”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: viññāṇam anattā iti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca viññāṇam anattā iti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: You say ‘No.’ …🔽When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘Yes.’ …

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato na ca “dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhanti vācam bhāsataḥ na ca dukkhanti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘No.’ …

original: “Idaṁ dukkhan”ti vācaṁ bhāsato “idaṁ dukkhan”ti ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti vācam bhāsataḥ idam dukkhan ti ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘Yes.’ …

original: “I”ti ca “dan”ti ca “du”ti ca “khan”ti ca ñāṇaṁ pavattatīti?
analyzed: iti ca ca ca ca ca ca ñāṇam pavattati iti
translated: When he says, ‘This is suffering,’ does knowledge occur that ‘This is suffering’?
You say ‘No.’ …
The Discussion of ‘This is Suffering’ is finished.
